articles.title: French Greetings and Goodbyes Guide
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import ConjugationTable from '@components/ConjugationTable.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Learning French together as a couple opens doors to romance, culture, and deeper connection. Whether you're planning a trip to Paris or simply want to add some *je ne sais quoi* to your relationship, mastering French greetings and goodbyes is the perfect starting point for your linguistic journey together.

## Why Learn French Greetings as a Couple?

French greetings aren't just words‚Äîthey're gateways to understanding French culture, romance, and social etiquette. When couples learn together, you create shared experiences, practice opportunities, and romantic moments that strengthen both your relationship and language skills.

## Essential French Greetings for Every Occasion

### Morning Greetings

Start your day with these beautiful French morning greetings:

<VocabCard
  word="Bonjour"
  translation="Good morning/Hello"
  pronunciation="[bon-ZHOOR]"
  example="Bonjour mon amour, as-tu bien dormi?"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Bonne matin√©e"
  translation="Have a good morning"
  pronunciation="[bun ma-tee-NAY]"
  example="Bonne matin√©e, √† tout √† l'heure!"
/>

### Afternoon and Evening Greetings

<VocabCard
  word="Bonsoir"
  translation="Good evening"
  pronunciation="[bon-SWAHR]"
  example="Bonsoir ch√©rie, comment √©tait ta journ√©e?"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Salut"
  translation="Hi/Bye (informal)"
  pronunciation="[sa-LUU]"
  example="Salut mon c≈ìur, √ßa va?"
/>

## Romantic Greetings for Couples

### Terms of Endearment in Greetings

French couples often include terms of endearment in their greetings. Here are the most common ones:

| French Term | Pronunciation | English Translation | When to Use |
|-------------|--------------|--------------------|--------------|
| Mon amour | [mon na-MOOR] | My love | Any time, very romantic |
| Mon ch√©ri/Ma ch√©rie | [mon shay-REE] | My dear/darling | Daily affection |
| Mon c≈ìur | [mon KUR] | My heart | Intimate moments |
| Ma belle/Mon beau | [ma BELL/mon BOH] | My beautiful one | Complimentary greeting |

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Bonjour mon amour"
  translation="Good morning my love"
  pronunciation="[bon-ZHOOR mon na-MOOR]"
  context="Perfect romantic morning greeting for your partner"
/>

<CultureTip title="The Art of French Kissing... Greetings!" flag="üá´üá∑">
In France, greeting with kisses on the cheek (la bise) is common among friends and family. The number of kisses varies by region‚ÄîParis typically does two, starting with the right cheek. For couples learning French culture, practice this greeting to understand French social customs!
</CultureTip>

## Formal vs. Informal Greetings

Understanding when to use formal versus informal greetings is crucial in French culture:

### Formal Greetings
- **Bonjour Monsieur/Madame** [bon-ZHOOR muh-SYUH/ma-DAM] - Good day Sir/Madam
- **Bonsoir Monsieur/Madame** [bon-SWAHR muh-SYUH/ma-DAM] - Good evening Sir/Madam
- **Enchant√©(e)** [ahn-shahn-TAY] - Pleased to meet you

### Informal Greetings
- **Salut** [sa-LUU] - Hi/Bye
- **Coucou** [koo-KOO] - Hey there (very casual)
- **√áa va?** [sa VAH] - How's it going?

## Beautiful French Goodbyes

### Standard Farewells

<VocabCard
  word="Au revoir"
  translation="Goodbye"
  pronunciation="[oh ruh-VWAHR]"
  example="Au revoir mon ch√©ri, √† ce soir!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="√Ä bient√¥t"
  translation="See you soon"
  pronunciation="[ah bee-ahn-TOH]"
  example="√Ä bient√¥t ma belle, tu vas me manquer."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="√Ä tout √† l'heure"
  translation="See you later (today)"
  pronunciation="[ah too tah LUR]"
  example="√Ä tout √† l'heure, bon travail!"
/>

### Romantic Farewells

<VocabCard
  word="Je t'aime"
  translation="I love you"
  pronunciation="[zhuh TEHM]"
  example="Je t'aime, passe une belle journ√©e."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Tu vas me manquer"
  translation="I'm going to miss you"
  pronunciation="[tuu vah muh mahn-KAY]"
  example="Tu vas me manquer, reviens vite!"
/>

## Time-Specific Goodbyes

### Evening and Night Farewells

<VocabCard
  word="Bonne nuit"
  translation="Good night"
  pronunciation="[bun NWEE]"
  example="Bonne nuit mon amour, fais de beaux r√™ves."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Dors bien"
  translation="Sleep well"
  pronunciation="[dor bee-AHN]"
  example="Dors bien ma ch√©rie, √† demain."
/>

<CultureTip title="French Time Etiquette" flag="üá´üá∑">
"Bonne nuit" is only used when someone is actually going to sleep, unlike English where "good night" can be used as a general evening farewell. Use "bonsoir" for evening goodbyes when you're not going to bed!
</CultureTip>

## Interactive Dialogue Practice for Couples

Here's a romantic morning dialogue you can practice together:

**Partner A:** *Bonjour mon amour, as-tu bien dormi?* [bon-ZHOOR mon na-MOOR, ah-tuu bee-AHN dor-MEE?]
(Good morning my love, did you sleep well?)

**Partner B:** *Oui, tr√®s bien merci. Et toi, mon c≈ìur?* [wee, tray bee-AHN mer-SEE. ay TWAH, mon KUR?]
(Yes, very well thank you. And you, my heart?)

**Partner A:** *Parfaitement, surtout dans tes bras.* [par-fet-MAHN, suur-TOO dahn tay BRAH]
(Perfectly, especially in your arms.)

## Evening Goodbye Dialogue

**Partner A:** *Je dois y aller maintenant. Tu vas me manquer.* [zhuh dwah zee ah-LAY man-tuh-NAHN. tuu vah muh mahn-KAY]
(I have to go now. I'm going to miss you.)

**Partner B:** *Toi aussi. √Ä tout √† l'heure, je t'aime.* [twah oh-SEE. ah too tah LUR, zhuh TEHM]
(Me too. See you later, I love you.)

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

1. **Don't use "Bonne nuit" as a general goodbye** - It's specifically for bedtime
2. **Remember the liaison** - "Bon" becomes "bonn" before vowels (Bonne apr√®s-midi)
3. **Match the formality level** - Don't mix "salut" with "Monsieur/Madame"
4. **Use appropriate terms of endearment** - Some are more intimate than others

## Cultural Context: French Greeting Customs

<CultureTip title="Regional Variations" flag="üá´üá∑">
French greetings can vary significantly by region. In the South, people tend to be more warm and expressive, while Northern regions may be more reserved. When visiting different French regions as a couple, observe local customs and adapt accordingly!
</CultureTip>

## Practice Exercises for Couples

### Morning Routine Challenge
For one week, greet each other only in French every morning. Start with basic "Bonjour" and gradually add terms of endearment and longer phrases.

### Role-Play Scenarios
1. **Meeting French friends** - Practice formal introductions
2. **Caf√© encounter** - Greet the waiter and each other
3. **Bedtime ritual** - Sweet French goodnights

### Memory Game
Take turns saying a French greeting or goodbye. Your partner must respond appropriately and add a term of endearment. Keep the conversation going as long as possible!

## Building Your French Foundation Together

Mastering greetings and goodbyes is just the beginning of your French journey as a couple. These essential phrases will:

- Build confidence for future conversations
- Create romantic moments in your daily routine
- Prepare you for French-speaking environments
- Strengthen your bond through shared learning

Remember, language learning is a marathon, not a sprint. Be patient with each other, celebrate small victories, and enjoy the romantic journey of discovering French together.

*Bonne chance et bon voyage dans votre apprentissage du fran√ßais!* (Good luck and good journey in your French learning!)

<CTA text="Ready to master French together?" buttonText="Start Learning Now" />

## Preparing Your Proposal

### Practice Tips
1. **Record yourself** saying the proposal
2. **Practice with your partner's name**
3. **Time your delivery** for natural flow
4. **Prepare for emotion** - it's okay to be nervous

### Setting the Scene
Consider these romantic elements:
- A meaningful location
- The right moment
- Having someone to photograph (secretly!)
- The anillo ready and accessible
